cards.front:
Frequent reassessments of the patient with face or neck injuries are most important because:

A. they lend credibility to your documentation.
B. rapid facial swelling might mask hidden injuries.
C. hospital staff require frequent patient updates.
D. such injuries can affect the respiratory system.
See Patient Assessment
cards.back: such injuries can affect the respiratory system.

cards.front:
Facial injuries should be identified and treated as soon as possible because:

A. of the risk for airway problems.
B. the spine might be injured as well.
C. swelling might mask hidden injuries.
D. bleeding must be controlled early.
See Patient Assessment
cards.back: of the risk for airway problems.

cards.front:
The mastoid process is located approximately:

A. 1 inch posterior to the external opening of the ear.
B. 1 inch posterior to the angle of the mandible.
C. 1 inch inferior to the external opening of the ear.
D. ½ inch anterior to the external opening of the ear.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: 1 inch posterior to the external opening of the ear.

cards.front:
The upper jawbones are called the:

A. mandible.
B. zygoma.
C. mastoid.
D. maxillae.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: maxillae.

cards.front:
What is the function of the sternocleidomastoid muscle?

A. Allows flexion of the neck
B. Connects the scapulae together
C. Provides respiration
D. Allows movement of the head
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: Allows movement of the head

cards.front:
Which of the following findings would be least suggestive of a head injury?

A. Briskly constricting pupils when exposed to light
B. Failure of the eyes to follow movement of an object
C. One pupil larger in size than the other pupil
D. Failure of the eyes to move in the same direction
See Emergency Medical Care for Specific Injuries
cards.back: Briskly constricting pupils when exposed to light

cards.front:
The lower jawbone is called the:

A. mandible.
B. maxillae.
C. mastoid.
D. zygoma.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: mandible.

cards.front:
The skin and underlying tissues of the face:

A. are well protected by the maxillae and mandible.
B. contain a relatively small number of nerve fibers.
C. have a rich blood supply and bleed profusely.
D. swell minimally when exposed to blunt trauma.
See Injuries of the Face and Neck
cards.back: have a rich blood supply and bleed profusely.

cards.front:
The Adam’s apple is:

A. below the thyroid cartilage and forms the upper part of the trachea.
B. the small indentation in between the thyroid and cricoid cartilages.
C. the lower part of the larynx that is formed by the cricoid cartilage.
D. the upper part of the larynx that is formed by the thyroid cartilage.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: the upper part of the larynx that is formed by the thyroid cartilage.

cards.front:
The conjunctiva are kept moist by fluid produced by the:

A. lacrimal gland.
B. corneal duct.
C. posterior orbit.
D. optic chiasma.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: lacrimal gland.

cards.front:
The term “hyphema” is defined as:

A. compression of one or both optic nerves.
B. blood in the anterior chamber of the eye.
C. an acute rupture of the globe of the eye.
D. inflammation of the iris, cornea, and lens.
See Emergency Medical Care for Specific Injuries
cards.back: blood in the anterior chamber of the eye.

cards.front:
The superficial temporal artery can be palpated:

A. at the angle of the jaw.
B. slightly above the ear.
C. just anterior to the tragus.
D. over the mastoid process.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: just anterior to the tragus.

cards.front:
When a light is shone into the pupil:

A. it should become smaller in size.
B. the opposite pupil should dilate.
C. both pupils should dilate together.
D. it should become larger in size.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: it should become smaller in size.

cards.front:
When transporting a patient with a facial injury, it is most important to be as descriptive as possible with the hospital regarding the patient’s injuries because:

A. most patients with facial trauma will need surgery.
B. they might need to call a specialist to see the patient.
C. it saves time on repeat assessments at the hospital.
D. they must make arrangements for an ICU bed.
See Patient Assessment
cards.back: they might need to call a specialist to see the patient.

cards.front:
The white portion of the eye is called the:

A. iris.
B. retina.
C. cornea.
D. sclera.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: sclera.

cards.front:
Bleeding from soft-tissue injuries to the face is most effectively controlled with:

A. digital pressure to an adjacent pulse point.
B. direct pressure using dry, sterile dressings.
C. pressure dressings and chemical ice packs.
D. ice packs and elevation of the patient’s head.
See Emergency Medical Care
cards.back: direct pressure using dry, sterile dressings.

cards.front:
The small, rounded, fleshy bulge immediately anterior to the ear canal is called the:

A. pinna.
B. stapes.
C. tragus.
D. incus.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: tragus.

cards.front:
The inner surface of the eyelids and the exposed surface of the eye itself are covered by a delicate membrane called the:

A. cornea.
B. sclera.
C. retina.
D. conjunctiva.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: conjunctiva.

cards.front:
The cricoid cartilage:

A. is easier to see and palpate than the thyroid cartilage.
B. is the only complete circular cartilage of the trachea.
C. lies superior to the thyroid cartilage in the neck.
D. lies superior to the cricothyroid membrane in the neck.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: is the only complete circular cartilage of the trachea.

cards.front:
The eyeball itself is referred to as the:

A. globe.
B. cornea.
C. orbit.
D. sclera.
See Anatomy and Physiology
cards.back: globe.
